facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 1356 of 1956 was filed.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeal No. 1356 of 1956.

facts.text: Appeal from the judgment and decree dated December 3, 1965 of the Calcutta High Court in Appeal from Original Decree No. 85 of 1965.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and decree dated December 3, 1965 of the Calcutta High Court in Appeal from Original Decree No. 85 of 1965.

facts.text: N. Mukherjee appeared for the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: N. Mukherjee, for the appellant.

facts.text: C. Bhandare, Pratap Singh and K. Rajendra Chaudhuri appeared for respondent No. 1.

anchor.surface_text: C. Bhandare, Pratap Singh and K. Rajendra Chaudhuri, for respondent No. 1.

facts.text: Judgment delivered by Grover, J.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by Grover, J.

facts.text: Appeal by certificate from a judgment of the Calcutta High Court.

anchor.surface_text: This is an appeal by certificate from a judgment of the Calcutta High Court.

facts.text: Ratanamala Dassi died intestate in January 1964.

anchor.surface_text: One Ratanamala Dassi ... died intestate in January 1964 leaving no issue or lineal descendants.

facts.text: Ratanamala Dassi was governed by the Bengal School of Hindu Law as modified by the Hindu Succession Act 1956.

anchor.surface_text: One Ratanamala Dassi who was governed by the Bengal School of Hindu Law as modified by the Hindu Succession Act 1956, hereinafter called the Act,

facts.text: Ratanamala Dassi left no issue or lineal descendants.

anchor.surface_text: leaving no issue or lineal descendants.

facts.text: Husband Monmotha Nath Dutt had predeceased Ratanamala Dassi.

anchor.surface_text: Her husband Monmotha Nath Dutt had predeceased her.

facts.text: Surviving heirs: appellant and respondents 2 and 3 (brothers of husband), respondent 1 Urmilla Sundari Dassi (husband's sister).

anchor.surface_text: The said Ratnamala Dassi left her surviving the appellant and respondents 2 and 3, the brothers of her husband and respondent 1, Urmilla Sundari Dassi her husbands sister.

facts.text: In 1964 respondent No. 1 instituted a suit for declaration of 1/4 share and partition.

anchor.surface_text: In 1964 respondent No. 1 instituted a suit for a declaration that as an heiress of Ratnamala Dassi she had 1/4 share in the movable and immovable property left by her and that she be allotted her share by partition of those properties.

facts.text: Appellant pleaded in written statement that brothers are heirs in preference to sister under the Act.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant entered appearance and took up the plea in his written statement that under the Act he and respondents 2 and 3 being the brothers of the husband of the deceased Ratnamala Dassi were the heirs in preference to respondent 1 who was the sister of the deceaseds husband.

facts.text: Suit tried by Single Judge of Calcutta High Court who granted preliminary decree on December 23, 1964 in favour of respondent 1 for 1/4 share.

anchor.surface_text: The suit was tried on the original side by a learned Single Judge of the Calcutta High Court who granted a preliminary decree on December 23, 1964 in favour of respondent 1 holding that she had 1/4 share in the estate left by Ratnamala Dassi.

facts.text: Appellant preferred appeal to division bench which was dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant preferred an appeal to a division bench which was dismissed.

facts.text: Sole issue: whether brother succeeds in preference to sister or jointly equal shares in Class II of Schedule to s.8 of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: The sole point which has to be considered is whether, according to the order of succession as laid down in Class II of the Schedule to s. 8 of the Act, brother would succeed in preference to the sister or whether the brother and sister would succeed jointly having equal shares ?

facts.text: Before High Court, appellant contended that numerals indicate order of precedence: brother (3) before sister (4).

anchor.surface_text: Before the High Court the contention raised on behalf of the appellant was that brother being prefixed by arabic numeral 3 came before sister which word had the numeral 4 before it and that the object of using the numerals within a particular group was to prescribe the order of precedence or preference.

facts.text: Division bench held numerals redundant, heirs in entry II take equally.

anchor.surface_text: The learned judges of the division bench felt that the use of the arabic numerals appeared to be redundant but the combined effect of this section read with the others seems to be that the legislature intended that the heirs named after numerals II,III IV composed three entries only.

facts.text: Supreme Court dismissed the appeal with costs.

anchor.surface_text: There is no merit in this appeal which fails and it is dismissed with costs.

facts.text: Property devolves under Entry (b) of s.15 upon heirs of the husband.

anchor.surface_text: We are concerned, in the present case, with Entry b which is secondly, upon the heirs of the husband.

facts.text: Ratnamala Dassi's property was her husband's property for succession purposes.

anchor.surface_text: As the property in the present case was of the husband of Ratnamala Dassi we have to turn to s. 8 to find out who would have been his heirs.
Bengal School of Hindu Law

arguments.court_reasoning: Numerals for convenient reference; cannot override substantive provisions like S.11; no provision made for such preference

arguments.claim: Arabic numerals redundant; combined effect of sections shows heirs after numerals II, III, IV compose three entries only

anchor.surface_text: The learned judges of the division bench felt that the use of the arabic numerals appeared to be redundant but the combined effect of this section read with the others seems to be that the legislature intended that the heirs named after numerals II,III IV composed three entries only.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: se in class 1 shall take simultaneously and to the exclusion of all other heirs and those m the first entry in class II shall be preferred to. those i

arguments.court_reasoning: Supreme Court agrees entries under Roman numerals; heirs within entry share equally per S.11

arguments.claim: Use of arabic numerals is not decisive on whether heirs in entry II Class II succeed simultaneously and equally

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to accede to the argument that the use of arabic numerals is decisive of the point whether or not the heirs specified in entry II of class II succeed simultaneously and equally. It is inconceivable that a matter of such importance should have been left to the employment of numerals alone.

arguments.claim: If legislature intended each arabic numeral group as separate entry, express provisions would have been made

anchor.surface_text: If the intention of the legislature was that each class of relatives shown against the arabic numerals constituted an entry express and specific provisions to that effect would have been made in the substantive sections of the Act.

arguments.claim: S.11 language inconsistent with arabic numeral heirs constituting separate entries

anchor.surface_text: Indeed s. Il says quite clearly that the property of an intestate shall be divided between the heirs specified in any one entry in class II of the Schedule so that they share equally. That language would not be consistent with the view that the heirs shown against the arabic numerals constitute an entry within the meaning of s. 11.

arguments.claim: S.11 would be unnecessary if heirs in same Class II entry take preference per numerals

anchor.surface_text: As noticed before it is that section which deals with the distribution of property among heirs in class II of the Schedule. Indeed s.11 would be wholly unnecessary if each one of the heirs mentioned in each entry of class II were to take preference to the next one in the same entry.

arguments.claim: No reason to prefer brother over sister in entry II when Class I treats male and female heirs equally

anchor.surface_text: It is also significant that in class 1 male and female heirs have been treated as equal. There is no reason why any distinction should have been made among the heirs in class II on the ground of the heir being male or female. For instance in entry II in class Il a brother would have preference over the sister

arguments.claim: Appellant's view would prefer son's daughter's son over son's daughter's daughter, counter to Act's equal treatment scheme

anchor.surface_text: Similarly on the appellants argument the sons daughters son should have preference over the sons daughters daughter. That again would run counter to the whole scheme of the Act that male and female heirs should get equal treatment.

arguments.claim: Act's principal reform is equal distribution between male and female heirs

anchor.surface_text: It must be remembered that the Act incorporated one of the principal reforms which had become a pressing necessity owing to the-changed social and economic conditions in Hindu society that in succession there should be equal distribution between male and female heirs.

arguments.claim: Numerals in statutes are for convenient reference and cannot override statutory provisions

anchor.surface_text: Generally speaking numbers or numerals are employed in a statute for the sake of convenient and easy reference but their use cannot override the statutory provisions.

arguments.claim: No indication in sections or Schedule for radical departure creating preference by numerals within Class II entries

anchor.surface_text: Nor is it possible in the absence of any indication in the sections or in the Schedule itself to attribute such a radical departure from the general scheme of classification of heirs, as has been suggested, namely, that in case of three entries only in class 11 the legislature intended to create an order of preference

holdings.text: The use of arabic numerals is not decisive of whether the heirs specified in entry II of Class II succeed simultaneously and equally; they do so succeed.

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to accede to the argument that the use of arabic numerals is decisive of the point whether or number the heirs specified in entry II of class II succeed simultaneously and equally. It is inconceivable that a matter of such importance should have been left to the employment of numerals alone.

holdings.reasoning_summary: S.11 mandates equal division among heirs in any one entry in Class II; inconceivable to leave important succession to numerals alone; no express provision for sub-entries.

holdings.text: Language of Section 11 is inconsistent with heirs against arabic numerals constituting separate entries; property divided equally among heirs in one entry.

anchor.surface_text: If the intention of the legislature was that each class of relatives shown against the arabic numerals constituted an entry express and specific provisions to that effect would have been made in the substantive sections of the Act. Indeed s. Il says quite clearly that the property of an intestate shall be divided between the heirs specified in any one entry in class II of the Schedule so that they share equally.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct textual reading of s.11 requires equal sharing in 'any one entry'; sub-division by numerals would contradict this clarity.

holdings.text: Arabic numerals in Class II entries are for convenient reference and cannot override statutory provisions like s.11.

anchor.surface_text: Generally speaking numbers or numerals are employed in a statute for the sake of convenient and easy reference but their use cannot override the statutory provisions.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Numerals aid reference but substantive rules in ss.9,11 govern order and distribution; no overriding effect without express indication.

holdings.text: No intention to create order of preference by arabic numerals within Class II entries; radical departure requires clear indication.

anchor.surface_text: Nor is it possible in the absence of any indication in the sections or in the Schedule itself to attribute such a radical departure from the general scheme of classification of heirs, as has been suggested, namely, that in case of three entries only in class 11 the legislature intended to create an order of preference

holdings.reasoning_summary: Harmonious reading of ss.8-16 and Schedule; s.11 unnecessary if preference by numerals; consistent with Act's equality scheme for male/female heirs.

holdings.text: Brothers and sister of the husband take equal shares in property devolving under s.15(1)(b) via Class II entry II of Schedule to s.8.

anchor.surface_text: There is no merit in this appeal which fails and it is dismissed with costs.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Application of ss.15(1)(b),16,8 Schedule Class II entry II read with s.11; rejects preference claim based on numerals.

justification_sets.label: Class II Schedule to Section 8, Hindu Succession Act support
